content:
RouteTable Class

In this Article

Stores the URL routes for an application.

Syntax

Declaration

[System.Runtime.CompilerServices.TypeForwardedFrom("System.Web.Routing, Version=3.5.0.0, Culture=Neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35")]
public class RouteTable

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • System.Object
  • RouteTable

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
,
Equals(Object,Object)
,
GetHashCode()
,
GetType()
,
MemberwiseClone()
,
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
,
ToString()

Remarks

Routes are URL patterns that are used for processing requests and that can be used to construct URLs dynamically. The Routes property is a static property (Shared in Visual Basic) that contains all the routes in an application that are used to specify how a URL request is matched to a class that handles the request. To specify a route, you add the route definition to the Routes property. Typically, you add routes to the Routes property from an event handler for the Application_Start event in the Global.asax file.

When an ASP.NET application handles a request, the application iterates through the collection of routes in the Routes property to find the route that matches the format of the URL request. The order of the routes that you add to the Routes property is significant, because the application uses the first route that it finds in the collection that matches the URL.

Constructors summary

RouteTable()

Initializes a new instance of the RouteTable class.

Properties summary

Routes

Gets a collection of objects that derive from the RouteBase class.

Constructors

  • RouteTable()

    Initializes a new instance of the RouteTable class.

    public RouteTable ();

Properties

  • Routes

    Gets a collection of objects that derive from the RouteBase class.

    public static System.Web.Routing.RouteCollection Routes { get; }

    Property Value

    • RouteCollection

      An object that contains all the routes in the collection.

    Remarks

    Routes are URL patterns that are used for processing requests and that can be used to construct URLs dynamically. The Routes property is a static property (Shared in Visual Basic) that represents all the objects that are used to specify how a URL request is matched to a class that handles the request. To specify a route, you add the route definition to the Routes property. Typically, you add routes to the Routes property from an event handler for the Application_Start event in the Global.asax file.

    When an ASP.NET application handles a request, the application iterates through the collection of routes in the Routes property to find the route that matches the format of the URL request. The order of the routes that you add to the Routes property is significant, because the application uses the first route in the collection that matches the URL.

    Example

    The following example shows how to add a Route object to the Routes property. 

        void Application_Start(object sender, EventArgs e) 
    {
        RegisterRoutes(RouteTable.Routes);
    }

    public static void RegisterRoutes(RouteCollection routes)
    {
        routes.Add(new Route
        (
             "Category/{action}/{categoryName}"
             , new CategoryRouteHandler()
        ));
    }

        Sub Application_Start(ByVal sender As Object, ByVal e As EventArgs)
        RegisterRoutes(RouteTable.Routes)
    End Sub
    
    Shared Sub RegisterRoutes(ByVal routes As RouteCollection)
        Dim urlPattern As String
        Dim categoryRoute As Route
        
        urlPattern = "Category/{action}/{categoryName}"
        
        categoryRoute = New Route(urlPattern, New CategoryRouteHandler)
        
        routes.Add(categoryRoute)
    End Sub
